data.title: Director of ‘King Kong’ and ‘The Towering Inferno’, John Guillermin dies

data.text:
Los Angeles, Sep 30 (EFE). — British director John Guillermin, known for The Towering Inferno (1974) and King Kong (1976), died Sunday of cardiac arrest at the age of 89 at his home in California’s Topanga Canyon, his family said Thursday.

Guillermin’s wife confirmed his death on Facebook, referring to him as “sensitive and passionate, full of a fierce rapture himself.”

The director’s prolific career, which began in the late 1940s, include works such as Death on the Nile, Shaft in Africa, The Blue Max, P.J and House of Cards, with George Peppard starring in the last three.

He also collaborated with Peter Sellers in Never Let Go and Waltz of the Toreadors.

The Towering Inferno, starring Paul Newman, Steve McQueen, William Holden and Faye Dunaway, won the Oscars for original song, film editing and cinematography.

The movie was nominated for best film, and also won Golden Globe awards for Fred Astaire and Susan Flannery.

He directed ‘Skyjacked’ (1972), starring Charlton Heston, and later filmed his best known work, King Kong, produced by Dino De Laurentiis, in which the cast comprised of Jessica Lange, Jeff Bridges and Charles Grodin.

He also made two films on the character Tarzan; Tarzan’s Greatest Adventure (1959), featuring Gordon Scott, and Tarzan Goes to India (1962), this time starring Jock Mahoney.

More than two decades later, he returned to film another movie of the same genre, Sheena, during the making of which he lost his son MichaelJohn in a traffic accident.
